item.title: The Papers: Russian exile killed and flats attack fear
item.description: The news that police are treating the death of businessman Nikolai Glushkov as murder leads several papers.

item.title: Jose Mourinho: Man Utd boss in part two of extraordinary news conference
item.description: Jose Mourinho concludes a remarkable news conference with references to "idiots", "idealists" and the "dictionary of life".

item.title: Russian Nikolai Glushkov's London death now a murder inquiry
item.description: UK police launch murder investigation after death of Russian businessman Nikolai Glushkov in south-west London

item.title: Botswana's Ian Khama: Trump encouraging elephant poaching
item.description: Overturning a ban on importing hunting trophies threatens elephants, says Ian Khama.

item.title: Cheltenham Festival: BHA to carry out review after six horse deaths at event
item.description: The British Horseracing Authority is to carry out a review after six horses died at the four-day Cheltenham Festival.

item.title: 'Mini Beast from the East' brings fresh snow warnings
item.description: The Met Office warns parts of north-eastern Scotland and England could see up to 20cm of snow.

item.title: Women's Six Nations: France beat Wales 33-8 to seal Grand Slam
item.description: Watch a selection of France's best tries as they beat Wales 33-8 in their final game of the 2018 Women's Six Nations, sealing the Grand Slam.

item.title: Spy poisoning: Putin most likely behind attack - Johnson
item.description: Boris Johnson says Vladimir Putin is "overwhelmingly likely" to have ordered Salisbury attack on ex-spy.

item.title: Video assistant referees agreed for World Cup
item.description: Video assistant referees will be used at this year's World Cup, after football's world governing body approves the technology.

item.title: Six Nations: England women win final match, but miss out on title
item.description: England women comfortably defeat Ireland in their final match of the Six Nations but are denied the title as France beat Wales.

item.title: Bacteria found in water at Glasgow Royal Hospital for Children
item.description: Three children are being treated for infections which may be linked to contamination of the water supply.

item.title: Keep it quiet later! Jools in battle with venue next door
item.description: The renowned pianist kept a diary chronicling the "noisy hubbub" outside his Kent country manor.

item.title: Swiss pianist gives concert on ice in northern Baltic Sea
item.description: Swiss pianist Gabriel Arnold performs for tourists on an icebreaker in Scandinavia's Gulf of Bothnia.

item.title: Parsons Green attack: Iraqi teenager convicted over Tube bomb
item.description: Ahmed Hassan is found guilty of attempted murder after injuring 30 commuters at Parsons Green.

item.title: 'Marauding predator' Jake Killick jailed for sex attacks
item.description: The 23-year-old was convicted of rape, sexual assault, false imprisonment and robbery.

item.title: JFK's never-delivered Dallas speech recreated
item.description: The voice of JFK has been used to reconstruct the speech he was due to deliver on the day he was assassinated.

item.title: James finally finishes Sport Relief Challenge
item.description: The Radio 1 DJ has completed his Sport Relief Pedal to the Peaks challenge

item.title: The women bringing animated adventures to life
item.description: A record number of women were nominated at the recent British Animation Awards, but men still dominate the industry.

item.title: Six Nations 2018: Ireland face England with Grand Slam in sights
item.description: Ireland need to beat reigning Six Nations champions England at Twickenham to clinch only the third Grand Slam title in their history.

item.title: Cheltenham Festival: Native River romps to Gold Cup success
item.description: Native River romps to victory in the Gold Cup at Cheltenham to give Richard Johnson his second victory in the Festival's showpiece race.

item.title: Mourinho defends record with 12-minute speech
item.description: Watch Manchester United manager Jose Mourinho's extraordinary speech defending his record.

item.title: Rapist caught after urinating in plant pot 30 years later
item.description: Two unsolved rapes were linked to Eric McKenna after police were called to a neighbour dispute.

item.title: Skiers jump from speeding lift in Georgia
item.description: Several people were injured when the out of control lift started going backwards fast, in Georgia.

item.title: Will Danny Boyle direct the next Bond film? Here's what we know so far
item.description: The Slumdog Millionaire director says he's working on the next film with Trainspotting's John Hodge.

item.title: Champions League draw: Liverpool face Manchester City in quarter-finals
item.description: Manchester City are drawn against Liverpool in an all-Premier League Champions League quarter-final.

item.title: Life of Pi actor Khan has rare tumour
item.description: Irrfan Khan has acted in over 100 films, including Slumdog Millionaire and The Amazing Spider-Man.

item.title: Four parents who take term-time holidays explain why
item.description: Some say they actively budget for fines, while others believe the penalty system is a "mess".

item.title: Anger over 'Blackface' makeup segment on Pakistan TV
item.description: A television show darkened models' faces and asked contestants to "transform" them into beautiful brides.

item.title: The fantasist bomber who wanted attention
item.description: Ahmed Hassan came to the UK for "a better life" but used a gift card he won at college to buy bomb-making materials.

item.title: Child sexual exploitation: How the system failed
item.description: Grooming, rape and trafficking are just some of the ways children in the UK are being sexually exploited.

item.title: Banksy protest artwork unveiled in New York
item.description: The anonymous artist reveals a new work in New York, drawing attention to a jailed Kurdish painter.

item.title: Winter Paralympics: The explosion that got me to the Paras
item.description: Owen Pick signed up to the Army when he was 16 years old, two years later he would be caught up in an explosion and take up para-snowboarding.

item.title: Footage of first polar bear cub born in UK in 25 years
item.description: The "confident and curious" cub was born at Highland Wildlife Park in Kincraig, Scotland.

item.title: John Boyega: Inclusion riders are fantastic
item.description: The Star Wars actor tells Newsbeat he's 100% interested in his production company using inclusion riders on future projects

item.title: Poisoned ex-spy: Why does UK think it was Russia?
item.description: The BBC's Gordon Corera considers the attack on Sergei Skripal and his daughter in Salisbury.

item.title: Tracy Beaker is back as a single mum - like these women who grew up in care
item.description: As Tracy returns as an adult, Newsbeat talks to two women who grew up in care and are now single parents.

item.title: ‘Integration? It’s about top exam grades’
item.description: Two of England's top schools are Muslim schools in Blackburn. What's their view on integration?

item.title: UK has 'massive problem' with confident women
item.description: "Women shouldn't feel that if they come across as too confident it can be mistaken for arrogance."

item.title: A better way to care for dementia patients
item.description: Infrared technology and artificial intelligence offer a better way to take care of dementia patients. It can scan their vital signs 24 hours a day.

item.title: How to become a professional shopper
item.description: Up to a million people are employed around the world as professional shoppers for clients in China.

item.title: Are 'cryonic technicians' the key to immortality?
item.description: Freezing the deceased in the hope of one day reviving them could become a mainstream service, advocates say.

item.title: How I saw Stephen Hawking's death as a disabled person
item.description: Why one disabled BBC journalist has found the reporting of Stephen Hawking's death troubling.

item.title: Adapt or die: How to cope when the bots take your job
item.description: In the first of our Future of Work series, we look at how new tech could change our working lives.

item.title: Russian spy: Veteran broadcaster fears for UK-Russia relations
item.description: Veteran broadcaster Vladimir Posner says UK-Russia relations are the worst he has ever known.

item.title: Several killed, cars crushed in Florida foot bridge collapse
item.description: Six to 10 people were killed when a newly installed pedestrian bridge spanning several lanes of traffic collapsed at Florida International University on Thursday, U.S. Senator Bill Nelson of Florida told local TV station CBS Miami. Emergency personnel searched for signs of life amid the wreckage of concrete, twisted metal and that rained from the collapsed structure and crushed vehicles on one of the busiest roads in South Florida.

item.title: Quiz: The Finns are happy, but who is not?
item.description: 7 days quiz: It's the weekly news quiz - have you been paying attention to what's been going on in the world over the past seven days?

item.title: Mueller witness is convicted pedophile with shadowy past
item.description: It was a few days before the one-year anniversary of President Donald Trump's inauguration and a Lebanese-American businessman was on his way to Mar-a-Lago. George Nader, an international fixer whose long history included intrepid back-channel mediation between Israel and Arab countries - and a 15-year-old pedophilia conviction in Europe that has not been previously reported - was transiting through Dulles International Airport outside Washington.

item.title: US accuses Russia of hacking energy grid, imposes sanctions for election meddling
item.description: The Trump administration accused Russia on Thursday of a concerted, ongoing operation to hack and spy on the U.S. energy grid and other critical infrastructure, and separately imposed sanctions on Russian officials for alleged high-tech interference in the 2016 American presidential election. U.S. national security officials said the FBI, the Homeland Security Department and American intelligence agencies determined that Russian intelligence and others were behind the attacks on the energy sector.

item.title: 'I tried to kill myself nine times before the NHS helped me'
item.description: At the age of 17 Sherry Denness tried to kill herself nine times in 10 days, and only then got the help she needed.

item.title: Bay Area members of Congress move to protect work permits for H-1B visa holdersa spouses
item.description: Six Bay Area members of Congress have signed onto a letter asking the Department of Homeland Security to scrap a plan to prevent spouses of H-1B visa holders from obtaining work permits. The department in December announced the plan , citing President Donald Trump's "Buy American and Hire American" executive order, and said it would carry out the plan this year.
